column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity|centering
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) In a case before the Chief Justice and the Court, it is argued that a 2016 licensing of Warhol's Orange Prince does not infringe the copyright of Ms. Goldsmith, who created the photograph the work was based on, since Warhol added tranformative meaning in accordance with precedent from Campbell and the 4 Factor Test, motivating a reversal of the Second Circuit's prior decision.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022; postedited) A lawyer argues before the Supreme Court that Warhol's Prince Series should be protected as fair use under copyright law since it conveyed a fundamentally different artistic meaning from Goldsmith's original photograph, while warning that ruling otherwise would harm artistic expression and creativity.

#Summary3=(gpt4o; postedited) A lawyer argued that Andy Warhol's "Prince Series" should be considered transformative under fair use law because it conveys a different meaning from Goldsmithâ€™s original photograph, asserting that the legal precedent supports this view while emphasizing the importance of transformative works for artistic expression and innovation.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The Supreme Court is considering whether Warhol's Prince Series is a transformative work and should be deemed fair use, despite Goldsmith's copyright claims, in an appeal where the lower courts disagreed on the role of meaning or message in the fair use analysis.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct; postedited) This discussion argues that transformative meaning should be considered in fair use analysis and supports this position by emphasizing its alignment with precedent, maintaining a balance between artist rights and creative freedom, and highlighting the high stakes for modern art, while also providing an example where a book-to-movie adaptation might fail the proposed test.

#Text=Mr. Chief Justice , and may it please the Court : Both courts below agreed and Goldsmith does n't dispute that Warhol 's Prince Series can reasonably be perceived to convey a fundamentally different meaning or message from Goldsmith 's photograph .
#Text=The question in this case is whether that different meaning or message should play a role , any role , in the fair use analysis .
#Text=Our answer is yes .
#Text=Warhol 's transformative meaning puts points on the board under Factor 1 of the four - factor balancing test .
#Text=Goldsmith and the Second Circuit say no .
#Text=Warhol 's new meaning is categorically irrelevant and ca n't be considered as part of Factor 1 or any other factor .
#Text=I want to emphasize three points .
#Text=First , the precedent supports us .
#Text=Campbell unambiguously requires an examination of meaning or message .
#Text=Google reaffirms that test and cites Warhol 's Soup Cans as a paradigmatic example of when it 's satisfied .
#Text=Goldsmith 's test is at odds with both cases .
#Text=Second , our approach , unlike Goldsmith 's , maintains a balance between protecting artists ' rights to monetize their works and encouraging new and important follow - on expression .
#Text=We give follow - on artists credit for innovation at Factor 1 while recognizing that Factor 4 and the other factors will sometimes cut decisively the other way .
#Text=Goldsmith 's necessity test , by contrast , upends that balance .

#Text=It banishes transformative meaning from the equation altogether , and by doing so , it violates 107 's text , contradicts precedent , and undermines copyright 's key goal , promoting creativity for the public good .
#Text=Finally , the stakes for artistic expression in this case are high .
#Text=A ruling for Goldsmith would strip protection not just from the Prince Series but from countless works of modern and contemporary art .
#Text=It would make it illegal for artists , museums , galleries , and collectors to display , sell , profit from , maybe even possess a significant quantity of works .
#Text=It would also chill the creation of new art by established and up - and - coming artists alike .
#Text=These results are repugnant to copyright and to the First Amendment .
#Text=You should reject them .
#Text=We ask you to reaffirm Campbell and reverse the decision below .
#Text=Could you give us an example of any follow - on work that fails your test ?
#Text=Sure .
#Text=I think a classic example would be a -- a book - to - movie adaptation .
#Text=I think that would be a follow - on work .
#Text=It would be a derivative work .

#Text=I think , if you -- if someone were to , you know , try to do that , I think that the -- the original creator , the author of the book , could very easily assert that that was not fair use and would have a winning case under Factor 4 and probably also under Factor 1 .
#Text=And , certainly , that would be a kind of classic example of a follow - on work that would not count .
#Text=Why ?

#Text=I mean , derivative works are generally in a different medium , and almost all of them , even a dramatization on -- on theater or even a motion picture or a sequel , they add something new according to your definition in your brief .
#Text=So why should n't they be protected as well according to your theory ?
#Text=Yeah , I think -- I think there 's a Factor 4 issue and a Factor 1 issue .
#Text=I think the most obvious problem would be a Factor 4 problem for the person who 's trying to copy or -- or create the movie adaptation .
#Text=I -- I 'm sorry .
#Text=I read Factor 1 , the purpose and character of the use , including whether such use is of a commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes .
#Text=So what 's the use here ?
#Text=Is -- I think I have to look at a use under 1 as well .
#Text=So is the use the creation of the Prince Series by Warhol ?
#Text=Is it the 2016 license of the Orange Prince ?
#Text=That factor , I think , is telling me to look at a use .
#Text=So which use are you looking at ?
#Text=So -- so we think that both uses are directly implicated in this case .
#Text=I know there 's a significant amount of confusion between our side and the other side on this , so I 'd like to try to clarify it .

#Text=This case came about because Ms. Goldsmith contacted the foundation , asserted that -- that the -- the original Warhol works were infringing , demanded a quite substantial seven - figure sum of money , and also demanded the copyrights in the work .
#Text=I --
#Text=We then filed --
#Text=I 'm -- I 'm putting that aside .
#Text=Sure .
#Text=Okay ?
#Text=They can tell us whether they 're claiming -- I think they 're out of the statute of limitations , so they ca n't claim that .
#Text=But â€“
#Text=So I think the only thing they can claim under the statute is the 2016 license .

#Text=No , respectfully , Your Honor , that 's not right , because what they claimed in their -- in their brief -- in their complaint , and this is at JA 120 to 121 , was that they said that we were not allowed to invoke our copyright in the works .
#Text=And that was n't just a past question that 's sort of like water under the bridge because of the statute of limitations .
#Text=That has ongoing significance because , if we --
#Text=Alright .
#Text=So then I want to break them down .
#Text=Assume that it 's the creation .
#Text=I understand your argument .
#Text=It was a painting .
#Text=It was a comment on consumerism .
#Text=If that 's all he did , that 's one thing .
#Text=But let 's look at the 2016 license of Orange Prince , which is what I thought this case was about , but putting that aside , assume it 's that .
#Text=Okay .
#Text=Assuming -- assuming that we 're just talking about that piece of the case , the licensing use --
#Text=Right .
#Text=-- even with respect to the licensing use , you 'd still need to look at Factor 1 , which would look at -- at the purpose and character of the use .

#Text=And that would certainly encompass the fact that Warhol 's use , the image that 's being licensed , was transformative and created -- and -- and -- and infused a new meaning or message on top of Goldsmith 's original work .
#Text=That I give you -- I spot you .
#Text=It should be considered .
#Text=Well â€“
#Text=The Second Circuit did n't .
#Text=But then what do I do with the rest of Factor 1 , the purpose and use and -- and character of the use ?
#Text=Because that 's not just up to the author .
#Text=That 's up to what was made , what use was made of Orange Prince .
#Text=It was a highly commercial use .
#Text=Goldsmith also licensed her photographs to magazines , just as Warhol 's estate did .
